trans-unit.source: Redis Cluster Resource Manager Template
trans-unit.target: Redis Cluster Resource Manager Template

trans-unit.source: Learn to easily deploy a new Redis cluster on Ubuntu VMs using Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI and a Resource Manager template
trans-unit.target: Learn to easily deploy a new Redis cluster on Ubuntu VMs using Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI and a Resource Manager template

trans-unit.source: Redis is an open-source key-value cache and store, where keys can contain data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets and sorted sets.
trans-unit.target: Redis is an open-source key-value cache and store, where keys can contain data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets and sorted sets.

trans-unit.source: Redis supports a set of atomic operations on these data types.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports a set of atomic operations on these data types.

trans-unit.source: With the release of Redis version 3.0, Redis Cluster is now available in the latest stable version of Redis.
trans-unit.target: With the release of Redis version 3.0, Redis Cluster is now available in the latest stable version of Redis.

trans-unit.source: Redis Cluster is a distributed implementation of Redis where data is automatically sharded across multiple Redis nodes, with the ability to continue operations when a subset of nodes is experiencing failures.
trans-unit.target: Redis Cluster is a distributed implementation of Redis where data is automatically sharded across multiple Redis nodes, with the ability to continue operations when a subset of nodes is experiencing failures.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Redis Cache is a dedicated Redis cache service, managed by Microsoft, but not all Microsoft Azure customers want to use Azure Redis Cache.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Redis Cache is a dedicated Redis cache service, managed by Microsoft, but not all Microsoft Azure customers want to use Azure Redis Cache.

trans-unit.source: Some want to keep their Redis cache behind a subnet within their own Azure deployments, while others are more comfortable hosting their own Redis servers on Linux virtual machines in order to fully take advantage of all Redis features.
trans-unit.target: Some want to keep their Redis cache behind a subnet within their own Azure deployments, while others are more comfortable hosting their own Redis servers on Linux virtual machines in order to fully take advantage of all Redis features.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will walk through using a sample Azure Resource Manager template to deploy a Redis cluster on Ubuntu VMs within a subnet in a resource group in Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will walk through using a sample Azure Resource Manager template to deploy a Redis cluster on Ubuntu VMs within a subnet in a resource group in Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: In addition to Redis 3.0 Cluster, this template also supports deploying Redis 2.8 with Redis Sentinel.
trans-unit.target: In addition to Redis 3.0 Cluster, this template also supports deploying Redis 2.8 with Redis Sentinel.

trans-unit.source: Note that this tutorial will focus on the Redis 3.0 Cluster implementation.
trans-unit.target: Note that this tutorial will focus on the Redis 3.0 Cluster implementation.

trans-unit.source: The Redis cluster is created behind a subnet, so there is no public IP access to the Redis cluster.
trans-unit.target: The Redis cluster is created behind a subnet, so there is no public IP access to the Redis cluster.

trans-unit.source: As part of the deployment, an optional “jump box” can be deployed.
trans-unit.target: As part of the deployment, an optional “jump box” can be deployed.

trans-unit.source: This “jump box” is an Ubuntu VM deployed in the subnet as well, but it does expose a public IP address with an open SSH port that you can SSH to.
trans-unit.target: This “jump box” is an Ubuntu VM deployed in the subnet as well, but it does expose a public IP address with an open SSH port that you can SSH to.

trans-unit.source: Then from the “jump box”, you can SSH to all the Redis VMs in the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Then from the “jump box”, you can SSH to all the Redis VMs in the subnet.

trans-unit.source: This template utilizes a “t-shirt size” concept in order to specify a “Small”, “Medium”, or “Large” Redis Cluster setup.
trans-unit.target: This template utilizes a “t-shirt size” concept in order to specify a “Small”, “Medium”, or “Large” Redis Cluster setup.

trans-unit.source: When the Azure Resource Manager template language supports more dynamic template sizing, this could be changed to specify the number of Redis Cluster master nodes, slave nodes, VM size, etc. For now, you can see the VM size and the number of masters and slaves defined in the file azuredeploy.json in the variables tshirtSizeSmall, tshirtSizeMedium, and tshirtSizeLarge.
trans-unit.target: When the Azure Resource Manager template language supports more dynamic template sizing, this could be changed to specify the number of Redis Cluster master nodes, slave nodes, VM size, etc. For now, you can see the VM size and the number of masters and slaves defined in the file azuredeploy.json in the variables tshirtSizeSmall, tshirtSizeMedium, and tshirtSizeLarge.

trans-unit.source: The Redis Cluster template for the “Medium” t-shirt size creates this configuration:
trans-unit.target: The Redis Cluster template for the “Medium” t-shirt size creates this configuration:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Before diving into more details related to Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.
trans-unit.target: Before diving into more details related to Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create a Redis cluster by using a Resource Manager template from the GitHub template repository.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create a Redis cluster by using a Resource Manager template from the GitHub template repository.

trans-unit.source: Each step will include directions for both Azure PowerShell and the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Each step will include directions for both Azure PowerShell and the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\RedisCluster).
trans-unit.target: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\RedisCluster).

trans-unit.source: Substitute in the folder name of your local folder and run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Substitute in the folder name of your local folder and run these commands:

trans-unit.source: Clone the entire template repository by using a Git client of your choice, for example:
trans-unit.target: Clone the entire template repository by using a Git client of your choice, for example:

trans-unit.source: When the cloning is completed, look for the redis-high-availability folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.
trans-unit.target: When the cloning is completed, look for the redis-high-availability folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.

trans-unit.source: When you create a Redis cluster by using a template, you must specify a set of configuration parameters.
trans-unit.target: When you create a Redis cluster by using a template, you must specify a set of configuration parameters.

trans-unit.source: To see the parameters that you need to specify for the template in a local JSON file before running the command to create the Redis cluster, open the JSON file in a tool or text editor of your choice.
trans-unit.target: To see the parameters that you need to specify for the template in a local JSON file before running the command to create the Redis cluster, open the JSON file in a tool or text editor of your choice.

trans-unit.source: Look for the "parameters" section at the top of the file, which lists the set of parameters that are needed by the template to configure the Redis cluster.
trans-unit.target: Look for the "parameters" section at the top of the file, which lists the set of parameters that are needed by the template to configure the Redis cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here is the "parameters" section for the azuredeploy.json template:
trans-unit.target: Here is the "parameters" section for the azuredeploy.json template:

trans-unit.source: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.
trans-unit.target: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.

trans-unit.source: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (e.g., Azure PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.
trans-unit.target: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (e.g., Azure PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.

trans-unit.source: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing runtime values for all parameters.
trans-unit.target: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing runtime values for all parameters.

trans-unit.source: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.
trans-unit.target: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.

trans-unit.source: If you do not include a parameters file, Azure PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.
trans-unit.target: If you do not include a parameters file, Azure PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example you can find in the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example you can find in the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will need to provide valid values for the parameters storageAccountName, adminUsername, and adminPassword, plus any customizations to the other parameters:
trans-unit.target: Note that you will need to provide valid values for the parameters storageAccountName, adminUsername, and adminPassword, plus any customizations to the other parameters:

trans-unit.source: The parameter storageAccountName must be a non-existent, unique Storage account name that satisfies the naming requirements for a Microsoft Azure Storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).
trans-unit.target: The parameter storageAccountName must be a non-existent, unique Storage account name that satisfies the naming requirements for a Microsoft Azure Storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).

trans-unit.source: This Storage account will be created as part of the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: This Storage account will be created as part of the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON files.
trans-unit.target: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON files.

trans-unit.source: Then run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Then run these commands:

trans-unit.source: $RGName must be unique within your subscription.
trans-unit.target: $RGName must be unique within your subscription.

trans-unit.source: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the parameters JSON file (azuredeploy-parameters.json), and will start executing the template accordingly.
trans-unit.target: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the parameters JSON file (azuredeploy-parameters.json), and will start executing the template accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (test, production, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (test, production, etc.)

trans-unit.source: will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.
trans-unit.target: will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.

trans-unit.source: When deploying, please keep in mind that a new Azure Storage account needs to be created, so the name you provide as the Storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure Storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).
trans-unit.target: When deploying, please keep in mind that a new Azure Storage account needs to be created, so the name you provide as the Storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure Storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).

trans-unit.source: During the deployment, you will see something like this:
trans-unit.target: During the deployment, you will see something like this:

trans-unit.source: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.
trans-unit.target: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.

trans-unit.source: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>, and do the following:
trans-unit.target: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>, and do the following:

trans-unit.source: In the left-hand navigation bar, click Browse, and then scroll down and click Resource Groups.
trans-unit.target: In the left-hand navigation bar, click Browse, and then scroll down and click Resource Groups.

trans-unit.source: Select the resource group that you just created, to bring up the “Resource Group” blade.
trans-unit.target: Select the resource group that you just created, to bring up the “Resource Group” blade.

trans-unit.source: In the Monitoring section, select the “Events” bar graph.
trans-unit.target: In the Monitoring section, select the “Events” bar graph.

trans-unit.source: This will display the events for your deployment.
trans-unit.target: This will display the events for your deployment.

trans-unit.source: By clicking individual events, you can drill further down into the details of each operation made on behalf of the template.
trans-unit.target: By clicking individual events, you can drill further down into the details of each operation made on behalf of the template.

trans-unit.source: If you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the Storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network) after testing, use this command:
trans-unit.target: If you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the Storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network) after testing, use this command:

trans-unit.source: To deploy a Redis cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a resource group by specifying a name and a location:
trans-unit.target: To deploy a Redis cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a resource group by specifying a name and a location:

trans-unit.source: Pass this resource group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the above Azure PowerShell section for details) into the following command:
trans-unit.target: Pass this resource group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the above Azure PowerShell section for details) into the following command:

trans-unit.target: You can check the status of individual resource deployments by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: In order to create a robust and reusable approach to Resource Manager template design, additional thinking is required to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during deployment of a complex solution like Redis Cluster.
trans-unit.target: In order to create a robust and reusable approach to Resource Manager template design, additional thinking is required to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during deployment of a complex solution like Redis Cluster.

trans-unit.source: By leveraging Resource Manager template linking capabilities, resource looping, and script execution through related extensions, it’s possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.
trans-unit.target: By leveraging Resource Manager template linking capabilities, resource looping, and script execution through related extensions, it’s possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.

trans-unit.source: This diagram describes the relationships between all files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment:
trans-unit.target: This diagram describes the relationships between all files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>redis-files</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>redis-files</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json template for the Redis cluster.
trans-unit.target: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json template for the Redis cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you have not downloaded a copy of the template file, designate a local folder as the location for the file and create it (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\RedisCluster).
trans-unit.target: If you have not downloaded a copy of the template file, designate a local folder as the location for the file and create it (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\RedisCluster).

trans-unit.source: Fill in the folder name and run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Fill in the folder name and run these commands:

trans-unit.source: Open the azuredeploy.json template in a text editor or tool of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Open the azuredeploy.json template in a text editor or tool of your choice.

trans-unit.source: The following information describes the structure of the template file and the purpose of each section.
trans-unit.target: The following information describes the structure of the template file and the purpose of each section.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, you can see the contents of this template in your browser from <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, you can see the contents of this template in your browser from <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We mentioned already the role of azuredeploy-parameters.json, which will be used to pass a given set of parameter values during template execution.
trans-unit.target: We mentioned already the role of azuredeploy-parameters.json, which will be used to pass a given set of parameter values during template execution.

trans-unit.source: The "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json specifies parameters that are used to input data into this template.
trans-unit.target: The "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json specifies parameters that are used to input data into this template.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of a parameter for the “t-shirt size”:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of a parameter for the “t-shirt size”:

trans-unit.source: Notice that defaultValue may be specified, as well as allowedValues.
trans-unit.target: Notice that defaultValue may be specified, as well as allowedValues.

trans-unit.source: The "variables" section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.
trans-unit.target: The "variables" section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.

trans-unit.source: Basically this contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.
trans-unit.target: Basically this contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples that range from simple to more complex:
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples that range from simple to more complex:

trans-unit.source: The vmStorageAccountContainerName and vmStorageAccountDomain variables are examples of simple name/value variables.
trans-unit.target: The vmStorageAccountContainerName and vmStorageAccountDomain variables are examples of simple name/value variables.

trans-unit.source: vnetID is an example of a variable that is calculated at run time using the functions resourceId and parameters.
trans-unit.target: vnetID is an example of a variable that is calculated at run time using the functions resourceId and parameters.

trans-unit.source: machineSettings builds on these concepts even further by nesting the JSON object osImageReference in the machineSettings variable.
trans-unit.target: machineSettings builds on these concepts even further by nesting the JSON object osImageReference in the machineSettings variable.

trans-unit.source: vmScripts contains a JSON array, scriptsToDownload, which is calculated at run time using the concat and variables functions.
trans-unit.target: vmScripts contains a JSON array, scriptsToDownload, which is calculated at run time using the concat and variables functions.

trans-unit.source: If you want to customize the size of the Redis Cluster deployment, then you can change the properties of the variables tshirtSizeSmall, tshirtSizeMedium, and tshirtSizeLarge in the azuredeploy.json template.
trans-unit.target: If you want to customize the size of the Redis Cluster deployment, then you can change the properties of the variables tshirtSizeSmall, tshirtSizeMedium, and tshirtSizeLarge in the azuredeploy.json template.

trans-unit.source: Note: The totalMemberCountExcludingLast and totalMemberCount properties are needed because the template language currently does not have “math” operations.
trans-unit.target: Note: The totalMemberCountExcludingLast and totalMemberCount properties are needed because the template language currently does not have “math” operations.

trans-unit.source: More information regarding the template language can be found in MSDN at <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More information regarding the template language can be found in MSDN at <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The "resources" section is where most of the action happens.
trans-unit.target: The "resources" section is where most of the action happens.

trans-unit.source: Looking carefully inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases.
trans-unit.target: Looking carefully inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases.

trans-unit.source: The first is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that essentially invokes a nested deployment within the main one.
trans-unit.target: The first is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that essentially invokes a nested deployment within the main one.

trans-unit.source: The second is the templateLink property (and related contentVersion property) that makes it possible specify a linked template file that will be invoked, passing a set of parameters as input.
trans-unit.target: The second is the templateLink property (and related contentVersion property) that makes it possible specify a linked template file that will be invoked, passing a set of parameters as input.

trans-unit.source: These can be seen in this template fragment:
trans-unit.target: These can be seen in this template fragment:

trans-unit.source: From this first example it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files.
trans-unit.target: From this first example it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files.

trans-unit.source: Each file is responsible for part of the required deployment activities.
trans-unit.target: Each file is responsible for part of the required deployment activities.

trans-unit.source: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:
trans-unit.target: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:

trans-unit.source: shared-resource.json: contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.
trans-unit.target: shared-resource.json: contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Examples are Storage accounts used to store a VM’s OS disks, virtual networks, and availability sets.
trans-unit.target: Examples are Storage accounts used to store a VM’s OS disks, virtual networks, and availability sets.

trans-unit.source: jumpbox-resources.json: deploys the “jump box” VM and all related resources, such as network interface, public IP address, and the input endpoint used to SSH into the environment.
trans-unit.target: jumpbox-resources.json: deploys the “jump box” VM and all related resources, such as network interface, public IP address, and the input endpoint used to SSH into the environment.

trans-unit.source: node-resources.json: deploys all Redis Cluster node VMs and connected resources (network adapters, private IPs, etc.).
trans-unit.target: node-resources.json: deploys all Redis Cluster node VMs and connected resources (network adapters, private IPs, etc.).

trans-unit.source: This template also deploys VM extensions (custom scripts for Linux) and invokes a bash script to physically install and set up Redis on each node.
trans-unit.target: This template also deploys VM extensions (custom scripts for Linux) and invokes a bash script to physically install and set up Redis on each node.

trans-unit.source: The script to invoke is passed to this template in the machineSettings parameter of the commandToExecute property.
trans-unit.target: The script to invoke is passed to this template in the machineSettings parameter of the commandToExecute property.

trans-unit.source: All but one of the Redis Cluster nodes can be deployed and scripted in parallel.
trans-unit.target: All but one of the Redis Cluster nodes can be deployed and scripted in parallel.

trans-unit.source: One node needs to be saved until the end because the Redis Cluster setup can be run on only one node, and it must be done after all of the nodes are running the Redis server.
trans-unit.target: One node needs to be saved until the end because the Redis Cluster setup can be run on only one node, and it must be done after all of the nodes are running the Redis server.

trans-unit.source: This is why the script to execute is passed to this template; the last node needs to run a slightly different script that will not only install the Redis server, but also set up the Redis cluster.
trans-unit.target: This is why the script to execute is passed to this template; the last node needs to run a slightly different script that will not only install the Redis server, but also set up the Redis cluster.

trans-unit.source: Let’s drill down into how this last template, node-resources.json, is used, as it is one of the most interesting from a template development perspective.
trans-unit.target: Let’s drill down into how this last template, node-resources.json, is used, as it is one of the most interesting from a template development perspective.

trans-unit.source: One important concept to highlight is how a single template file can deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance, it can set unique values for required settings.
trans-unit.target: One important concept to highlight is how a single template file can deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance, it can set unique values for required settings.

trans-unit.source: This concept is known as resource looping.
trans-unit.target: This concept is known as resource looping.

trans-unit.source: When node-resources.json is invoked from within the main azuredeploy.json file, it is invoked from inside a resource that uses the copy element to create a loop of sorts.
trans-unit.target: When node-resources.json is invoked from within the main azuredeploy.json file, it is invoked from inside a resource that uses the copy element to create a loop of sorts.

trans-unit.source: A resource that uses the copy element will “copy” itself for the number of times specified in the count parameter of the copy element.
trans-unit.target: A resource that uses the copy element will “copy” itself for the number of times specified in the count parameter of the copy element.

trans-unit.source: For all settings where it is necessary to specify unique values between different instances of the deployed resource, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.
trans-unit.target: For all settings where it is necessary to specify unique values between different instances of the deployed resource, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.

trans-unit.source: In the following fragment from azuredeploy.json, you can see this concept applied to multiple VMs being created for the Redis Cluster nodes:
trans-unit.target: In the following fragment from azuredeploy.json, you can see this concept applied to multiple VMs being created for the Redis Cluster nodes:

trans-unit.source: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can see in the dependsOn JSON array.
trans-unit.target: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can see in the dependsOn JSON array.

trans-unit.source: In this particular template, you can see that the Redis Cluster nodes are dependent on the shared resources being created first.
trans-unit.target: In this particular template, you can see that the Redis Cluster nodes are dependent on the shared resources being created first.

trans-unit.source: As was previously mentioned, the last node needs to wait for provisioning until all other nodes in the Redis cluster have been provisioned with the Redis server running on them.
trans-unit.target: As was previously mentioned, the last node needs to wait for provisioning until all other nodes in the Redis cluster have been provisioned with the Redis server running on them.

trans-unit.source: This is accomplished in azuredeploy.json by having a resource named lastnode-resources that depends on the copy loop named memberNodesLoop from the template snippet above.
trans-unit.target: This is accomplished in azuredeploy.json by having a resource named lastnode-resources that depends on the copy loop named memberNodesLoop from the template snippet above.

trans-unit.source: After provisioning of memberNodesLoop is completed, lastnode-resources can be provisioned:
trans-unit.target: After provisioning of memberNodesLoop is completed, lastnode-resources can be provisioned:

trans-unit.source: Notice how the lastnode-resources resource passes a slightly different machineSettings.commandToExecute to the linked template.
trans-unit.target: Notice how the lastnode-resources resource passes a slightly different machineSettings.commandToExecute to the linked template.

trans-unit.source: This is because for the last node, in addition to the installed Redis server, it needs to call a script to set up the Redis cluster (which must be done only once after all the Redis servers are up and running).
trans-unit.target: This is because for the last node, in addition to the installed Redis server, it needs to call a script to set up the Redis cluster (which must be done only once after all the Redis servers are up and running).

trans-unit.source: Another interesting fragment to explore is the one related to the CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.
trans-unit.target: Another interesting fragment to explore is the one related to the CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.

trans-unit.source: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node.
trans-unit.target: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node.

trans-unit.source: In this case, this is used to install and set up Redis on each VM node.
trans-unit.target: In this case, this is used to install and set up Redis on each VM node.

trans-unit.source: Let’s look at a snippet from the node-resources.json template that uses these:
trans-unit.target: Let’s look at a snippet from the node-resources.json template that uses these:

trans-unit.source: You can see that this resource depends on the resource VM already being deployed (Microsoft.Compute/virtualMachines/vmMember, where is the parameter machineSettings.machineIndex, which is the index of the VM that was passed to this script using the copyindex() function).
trans-unit.target: You can see that this resource depends on the resource VM already being deployed (Microsoft.Compute/virtualMachines/vmMember, where is the parameter machineSettings.machineIndex, which is the index of the VM that was passed to this script using the copyindex() function).

trans-unit.source: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-node solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.
trans-unit.target: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-node solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.

trans-unit.source: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as highlighted by the following diagram:
trans-unit.target: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as highlighted by the following diagram:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>redis-template-structure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>redis-template-structure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In essence, this approach suggests to:
trans-unit.target: In essence, this approach suggests to:

trans-unit.source: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub-template executions.
trans-unit.target: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub-template executions.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific template file that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (Storage accounts, virtual network configuration, etc.).
trans-unit.target: Create a specific template file that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (Storage accounts, virtual network configuration, etc.).

trans-unit.source: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific to a given resource.
trans-unit.target: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific to a given resource.

trans-unit.source: For identical members of a group of resources (nodes in a cluster, etc.), create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.
trans-unit.target: For identical members of a group of resources (nodes in a cluster, etc.), create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.

trans-unit.source: For all post-deployment tasks (product installation, configurations, etc.), leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.
trans-unit.target: For all post-deployment tasks (product installation, configurations, etc.), leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
